availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

person.persName: Thomas Overton Moore (Louisiana governor and sugar planter)

body.p: Louisiana governor and sugar planter. Sampson County, North Carolina, native. Son of John Moore and Jean Overton Moore. Married to Bethiah Jane Leonard Moore on November 30, 1830. Father of Emma J. Moore. Moved to Rapides Parish, Louisiana, in 1829. Manager of Walter H. Overton's sugar plantation. Owned and operated a sugar plantation in Rapides Parish. Member of the House of Representatives in the State of Louisiana in 1848. Member of the Senate in the State of Louisiana in 1856. Member of the Democratic Party. Owned 226 enslaved persons in Rapides Parish in 1860. Fourteenth governor of the State of Louisiana from 1860 to 1864. Forced to relocate the Louisiana to capital to Opelousas, Louisiana, in 1862. Under threat of arrest, fled to Havana, Cuba.

ab.bibl:
Seventh Manuscript Census of the United States (1850), Population Schedules, Louisiana, Rapides Parish, p. 52B-53A.
Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Population Schedules, Louisiana, Rapides Parish, p. 201.
Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Slave Schedules, Louisiana, Rapides Parish, p. 28-31.
Nancy Capace, Encyclopedia of Louisiana (Somerset Publishers, 1999), 131-133.
John David Winters, The Civil War in Louisiana (Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press, 1991), 4.
Find A Grave, "Thomas Overton Moore (1804-1876)," Memorial #8385593, https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/8385593/thomas-overton-moore (accessed March 19, 2018).
